title: Tech's heroes are here to save us from the shorts
text:
Let’s cast our minds back to 2017 when Mike Cannon-Brookes said: "The Australian investment community has a lot of learning to do about technology. It's part of the reason we didn't list here.”

He was right. WiseTech became the most expensive tech stock in the world - more expensive than Atlassian - and now that’s some other company’s problem thanks to the bear market in WiseTech shares unleashed by JCapital Research’s Anne Stevenson-Yang.

While WiseTech denies her accusations that it is a $10 billion stock promoted with inflated growth, and has yet to respond to her secondary accusation that its acquisition strategy is a failure, it is the reactionary impulse of the tech industry rushing to the defence of WiseTech that invites disbelief.

JCap spent months trying to make sense of WiseTech’s accounts using public domain information and primary interview-based research. It went public with its conclusions. They may turn out to be wrong. (Evans and Partners thinks so; others may too).

It was not just the instinct to deify WiseTech, as if this were some character assassination of the entire community (leave that to me), but we then arrive at the predictable calls to fix the conduct of short sellers.
description: RIP Australian tech self-awareness. Cause of death: Anne Stevenson-Yang.
